newsitem.title: GERMANY: Board recommends IG Bau reject construction deal.
newsitem.headline: Board recommends IG Bau reject construction deal.

text.p: The main wages commission of Germany's IG Bau construction union on Monday said it had recommended to union leadership that it reject an arbitration-brokered pay deal.
Despite pleas from government officials not to strike, the commission had been expected to reject the deal, which was approved by a small majority in the arbitration committee.

The union said it may resort to strikes to secure 100 percent sick-pay benefits for its workers, rejecting the decision of the arbitration committee for workers to receive 80 percent pay for the first three weeks of sickness.
IG Bau leader Klaus Wiesenhuegel told a news conference in Frankfurt the union was prepared for further talks with employers and that it was prepared to compensate for sick pay costs in wage talks.

The decision made by the main wages commission on Monday will pass to the union's board for a final decision on whether to reject or accept the deal. If the deal is not approved by May 21, the IG Bau union can lawfully call industrial action.

Analysts believe any strike is likely to be limited since neither side can afford a prolonged dispute in a sector suffering from mass unemployment, with about 400,000 of its 1.3 million workers out of a job.

Officials from several regional units of the IG Bauen-Agrar-Umwelt (IG Bau) union signalled at the weekend that they were unhappy with the deal, which was reached last Thursday during a marathon negotiating session.
The controversial deal also recommended raising wages by 1.3 percent from last April 1 and reducing Christmas bonuses. German inflation stands at about 1.5 percent.
The IG Bau union had, among other demands, called for wage increase of 2.9 percent and continued full pay during annual sick leave while employers sought to keep pay unchanged.
Unoin officials particularly disliked the cutbacks in sick pay and the Christmas bonus. Government officials have urged the union and employers to accept the deal.

Construction minister Klaus Toepfer warned on Friday that a strike would be "poison" for the troubled sector. He noted that new building orders in Germany had fallen by 8.7 percent in January and February.
Labour minister Norbert Bluem also warned of the potentially devastating consequences for the sector of a strike in view of the current weakness in the construction industry.
